name: SnipBot Enterprise Techniques
description: TTPs identified in SnipBot's recent enterprise attacks

techniques.comment: SnipBot malware was observed doing execution through API.
SnipBot malware hides its tracks by using a window message-based control-flow obfuscation algorithm.
Registry key hijacking via COM Hijacking was seen in SnipBot malware for dropping DLL payload and executing it into Explorer.
SnipBot malware uses masquerading, pretending the original payload is a PDF file in an email link, or a downloader masked as a PDF file.
SnipBot uses control-flow obfuscation and encrypts command and control names to hinder malware analysis and static detection.
SnipBot uses process injection to run its code in the address space of another process by injecting the code directly into the process.
SnipBot uses the Windows task scheduler to perform a variety of actions such as restarting the computer or downloading additional files.
It was observed from the article that SnipBot malware has the capability to do access token manipulation.
SnipBot uses a command interpreter to execute commands, scripts or binaries.
SnipBot was able to collect information about the victim's system in the form of computer/domain name, MAC address, Windows build number etc.
It was observed that SnipBot malware uses the technique of data obfuscation.
SnipBot eradicates evidence of its presence by deleting registry keys and files.
SnipBot installation process suspiciously involves a valid code signing certificate, likely obtained through certificate theft or fraud to purchase a new certificate.
SnipBot uses a custom protocol for command and control.
SnipBot was seen trying to archive data for exfiltration.
SnipBot collects data from local system
The initial infection vector for SnipBot is through email that includes a link that redirects to the SnipBot downloader.
The Initial DLL payload (config-pdf.dll) used COM hijacking to register a file as the thumbnail cache library in the registry hive of the current user.
